ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to make progress on, structure, edit and present the linguistics senior essay
How to write a thesis. Writing skills and time management, generally.
I learned how to present my thesis, tips and tricks on how to motivate myself to work on demand, and how to finish my thesis.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think we spent too much time discussing strategy earlier in the semester-- I didn't find it helpful to exchange writing tips for two hours straight. However, I appreciated the times when we heard others' brief progress reports for maybe a half hour or so at the beginning and then set aside the rest of the time to work on writing-- the collective accountability format was nice.
I think the best thing that could be done is to incorporate more free research/write time in the class, akin to how some departments do research for credit.

I appreciated how this course kept students accountable throughout the thesis-writing process. It was hard to fall too far behind, given that there were regular checkpoints. I also liked the relaxed format of the class meetings themselves, where students could discuss their progress with their peers and get tips from one another.

I thought the due to advisor vs. due to department deadlines were a bit confusing, to be honest. If the goal was just to light a fire under the a**** of the students, it definitely worked in my case. If theres some other reason for having it be this way, i dont know maybe reevaluate that?

I really liked how we discussed the ways to motivate ourselves to work when we hit a slump. Jim's advice about how we need to put our projects into perspective and work on what we can finish in the "next two weeks" helped us realize what was doable and what was unrealistic in the time we had. I liked the practice thesis presentations at the end especially.  A major strength were the class work sessions, where we had quiet, structured time set aside to work on the thesis.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It's a requirement for the linguistics major and I don't think anyone else can take it, so I'm not sure how useful it is to say whether I recommend it or not, but I enjoyed hearing what others were working on every week, and writing together gave a sense of camaraderie.

This is a required course for the LING major, but I would still recommend it even if it were optional. It's hugely helpful to have a sense of structure while undertaking (most likely) your first project of this scale.

I recommend it (and it's a requirement) for all seniors in the linguistics department. The structure of Jim's course (and Raffaella's in the fall) really helps guide the linguistics seniors on the right path and get the work done in a timely manner.
